description: Collaborate with others on the cloud.

slides.title: Local vs Remote ‚òÅÔ∏è
slides.content:
# Distributed

- **Local:** The copy on your computer.
- **Remote:** The copy on a server (GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket).

They are separate repositories that you sync occasionally.

slides.title: git clone
slides.content:
# Copying üì•

The way to start working on an existing project.

`git clone https://github.com/user/project.git`

Downloads the entire repository history and sets up the remote link automatically.

slides.title: git remote
slides.content:
# The Link üîó

`git remote add origin https://...`

- **origin:** The standard nickname for the primary remote server.
- `git remote -v`: Lists all remotes.

slides.title: git push
slides.content:
# Uploading üì§

Send your committed changes to the remote.

`git push origin main`

(Send local 'main' branch to 'origin' server).

slides.title: git pull
slides.content:
# Downloading ‚è¨

Fetch changes from remote and merge them into your local branch immediately.

`git pull origin main`

Basically `fetch` + `merge` combined.

slides.title: Concept Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which command downloads changes AND merges them into your current branch?

slides.title: git fetch
slides.content:
# Safe Download üì¶

Downloads new data from remote but DOES NOT merge it into your code.

Allows you to see what others have done before deciding to merge.

`git fetch origin`

slides.title: Upstream Tracking
slides.content:
# Connection ü§ù

Link a local branch to a remote branch.

`git push -u origin main`

After running this once, you can just type `git push` or `git pull` without arguments.

slides.title: Pull Requests (PR)
slides.content:
# Code Review üßê

Not a Git command, but a GitHub/GitLab feature.

Instead of pushing directly to `main`, you push to a branch and ask for permission to merge.

Allows team discussion and review.

slides.title: Forking
slides.content:
# Copying Projects üç¥

Creating a server-side copy of someone else's repo under your account.

Standard workflow for Open Source contributions (Fork -> Clone -> Edit -> Push to Fork -> PR to Original).

slides.title: Origin vs Upstream
slides.content:
# Naming üè∑Ô∏è

In a Fork workflow:
- **origin:** Your fork (you have write access).
- **upstream:** The original repo (read-only for you).

You pull from upstream to stay current, push to origin.

slides.title: Workflow Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: In an open-source workflow, what is 'origin' usually?
quizOptions: The original repository created by the author

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: Remotes ‚òÅÔ∏è

Working together.

- **Clone:** Copy repo.
- **Push:** Upload.
- **Pull:** Download & Merge.
- **Fetch:** Download only.
